I don't know if anyone touched on this, but even though barbie was made with an unrealistic body, she was the *first* doll for girls that was not a baby. Where dolls for boys (actionfigures, also with unrealistic bodies mind you) were already aimed at being hero-type-role-models that boys could look up to, dolls for girls were soleley aimed at practising motherhood. Barbie was the first doll that showed girls a role model of a woman with a life and career of her own. I feel like the part where barbie actually did empower young girls is often very forgotten.

Cause Barbie much like Mario is an iconic brand thatâ€™s pretty much the face of their respective industry and has existed for decades and weâ€™re really popular in the 1980s and both had successful films last year and Bratz is essentially the Sonic of the doll industry in that both brands were created to compete with the dominant brand on their respective industries Mario for gaming and Barbie for dolls and bratz much like Sonic weâ€™re essentially embodiments of what each target consumer found cool and trendy in the decades they were created and both essentially were popular enough in their respective decades to rival the brand they were were created to best in sales but once the decades went by it seemed both Sonic and Bratz seemed to not have the same mainstream relevance they once had though Sonic at the moment seems to be going through a sort of renaissance at the moment with him having two successful theatrical films and recent games starting to be good

It doesnâ€™t hurt for someone to climb up Rapunzelâ€™s hair because she basically uses pulley mechanics to change where the tugging is being applied. Here she had it wrapped around a post (?) and in Disneyâ€™s version she hung it on a hook and held it from the other side. That way there isnâ€™t any direct pulling on her scalp. Same way people will hold their hair in a makeshift ponytail to brush out the ends- it tugs where your hand is rather than at the scalp.  Plus if someone climbed up directly applying pressure to the scalp Iâ€™d be more worried about her neck before her hair lol

Can we just talk about how the designs of the pixies are actually really unsettling? Bratz is known for its huge eyes, but the girl pixies have eyes that are way too big, even for their designs. Their eyes end where a normal Bratz's eyebrows would be, and are nearly wrapping around their head, giving them a crazed look. And it's so noticeable because their eye whites seem to not be shaded at all, making them really pop in their surroundings, almost like they're glowing.  It's such a subtle way to indicate that otherworldliness! (Is that a word?)

omg of course owls get horny, that's literally what the "breeding season" is. All vertebrates and arthropods get horny, probably others too. During said season, the specific amount of sunlight lets the brain know that it is the correct time to start producing hormones and that's when non-human animals get hormonal aka...horny. That's it. There is no difference between us and them. So there you go, in case you were curious.

Bratz was basically the iconic Y2K  doll and Barbie was still stuck in the 70s as far as fashion and inclusivity goes. I think Bratz was more inclusive of the black community and their pop culture contributions to that area of 1990/2000s as far as style, skin tone, fashion etc. Bratz were what cool girls had. Itâ€™s that era feel for some reason. When I got older and Monster High dolls came out I lost my mind. I was just a little too old for dolls but I adored them because they were gothic and cool and different. I also remember Moxie dolls being super cool. They were a mix of Bratz dolls with big heads/eyes/lips but they had detachable wigs (like Polly pockets of the era) AND they were bendable/posable with better proportions than Barbie. Barbie was JUST beginning to make bendable and posable Barbieâ€™s en mass at the time from what I can remember, and there wasnâ€™t much difference in body composition. I think a few years back I saw a thicker Barbie. I think she was advertised as â€œMomâ€ Barbie which tbh kind of rude. She had thicker thighs and waist essentially. I also saw recently a disco Barbie, she had an Afro and a really cool dress! But Iâ€™m unsure if it was a Mattel doll. I think Barbie did help with encouraging young girls to pursue stem fields, and encouraged girls to pursue higher education. My favorite Barbie from my childhood was one of the â€œSurferâ€ Barbies. They had proportionally big feet that did not fit into Barbie shoes. She was a black Barbie and smelled like coconuts and honestly she was cool and pretty AF. Like her hair was amazing. Looking back, a little weird that she was a surfer Barbie and there wasnâ€™t just a regular black Barbie, but I think I was 8 at the time so what can you do. I really do like that Mattel has branched out with their inclusivity in their doll lines, but I think when it comes to girlâ€™s toys, everything is going to be scrutinized heavily about â€œwhat it is teaching themâ€. Itâ€™s sort of ridiculous the type of pressure thatâ€™s out there and I donâ€™t feel that there is the same heavy stigmatism around boys action figures. I think that people will be people, and have insecurities, no matter if they play with a 1950s Barbie or a 2022 Barbie, or if they play with a G.I. Joe or a WWE wrestling figure. We put too much pressure on obtaining perfection in the culture, regardless of toys and what they look like.
Finally. The showdown I have been waiting for my entire life.

Actually, if you know a little bit about Scottish and Irish fairy folklore, some "gnomes" can be murderous. For all we know, that little guy's red hat was soaked in someone's blood. ğŸ‘€  "The redcap is a type of malevolent, murderous goblin found in Border folklore. He is said to inhabit ruined castles along the Anglo-Scottish border, especially those that were the scenes of tyranny or wicked deeds and is known for soaking his cap in the blood of his victims. He is also known as Redcomb and Bloody Cap."  I kinda get what the Bratz movie was trying to do with their own spin on pixie and fae lore. If only they executed it better.

In 70s/80s britain there were 2 dolls that rivaled Barbie. Pippa and Sindy. Two different doll lines. Pippa was similar to the bigger Polly Pocket with rubber clothes. Also the girls from ABBA dressed up as these dolls one time. (May have been the other way around, not sure).  Sindy however was more realistic and homey. You would get the doll and buy clothes and play sets seperatly. (I am unsure if this applied to Pippa as my mum only had one Pippa doll. It was a gift from her best friend.) In 70s/80s Britain you were either a Pippa girl or a Sindy girl. Barbie girl was not a term back then.

If you look at the shot you can see her hair is wrapped around the post. as long as it's wrapped around enough she wouldn't really feel him tugging on the end of it because he wouldn't be pulling it from her scalp. If you have long enough hair and hold onto the top of it you can tug as hard as you want on the end and it's not going to hurt you.

:)
Fun fact, in case you were wondering, its COMPLETELY PLAUSIBLE for a prince to climb Rapunzels hair. In Tangled, Rapunzel throws her hair over this little hook. That's what's called a pulley. The basic premise is that if you throw a rope around...pretty much anything (although generally a wheel or hook) it will loosen the pressure on the rope. The more wheels/hooks you use, the less pressure there is. So yeah, a prince could totally climb Rapunzels hair.

with the bratz v barbie realistic proportions thing, the difference is that barbie has unrealistic proportions on a mostly regular shaped body, while bratz go full cartoon. as a doll collector i do not and never have valued realistic proportions, and tbh prefer cartoon proportions. theyre more fun and its fun to go crazy. humans already look like humans, i dont want just a small human. its gotta look interesting, if i want to see a small human ill just look at someone from far away. also dolls are an art form, just as most things are. realistic sculpting is impressive, but its not fun for dress up or styling or looking at because you do all those things on REGULAR humans already! and with irl body expectations, its like using ferb from phineas and ferb as goals. you can visibly see that no human can ever physically look like that without doing math to figure out how he would look if he was real. barbie looks real enough you dont understand that its impossible to look like that unless you think real hard about it

I'm going to have to be a nerd/geek for a moment and supply some fantasy logic. Gothel waiting to cast the crazy powerful spell is most likely due to the fact that crazy powerful spells have crazy expensive costs. I've been playing Dungeons & Dragons and other home brew roleplaying games for over 16 years, and I have only played a spell caster maybe 3 times. That's because spells are stupid expensive, have ridiculous requirements (like needing specific sized hunks of metal, or doing weird hand waving shenanigans, etc.), and usually require the caster to focus on maintaining the spell constantly. The caster has to forego casting any other spells to maintain such powerful spells, unless you are some max level caster with multi-casting abilities. This means, in traditional fantasy RPG logic, Gothel has to focus on maintaining that barrier spell, sacrificing her ability to cast other spells without canceling the barrier spell first. Go ahead and correct/mock me in response, I'm just saying that the Barbie movie kind of did something correct there. Just a moment of fantasy correctness amongst a garbage fire of inconsistencies though... From a fantasy view, I feel that the Bratz movie is more unique. It is also full of inconsistencies, but most fantasy movies for children are that way.

Sasha represents anybody who is black, Jade is from Eastern Asia, and Cloe is white and/or any light-featured POC dpeending on how you look at them. That thing you were talking about when Rapunzel didn't even try to leave the tower, is called Learned Helplessness.   For extra sadness,  (Stop reading here if you don't want the sad stuff)  . . . Learned helplessness occurs when an individual continuously faces a negative, uncontrollable  situation and stops trying to change their circumstances, even when they have the ability to do so. we use learned helplessness in animals as a model to try and help humanity understand depression (of which I have) in humans.   Martin Seligman first observed learned helplessness when he was doing experiments on dogs. He noticed that the dogs didn't try to escape the shocks if they had been conditioned to believe that they couldn't escape.  Yeah, big oof. Also, thanks for the good laughs. Love your stuff.

3:44 actually, the reason Mattel sued is MGA didn't actually have the rights to Bratz, it was created by Carter Bryant while he was working at Mattel, in his office, and Mattel has a policy that anything made in the office is legally owned by them, as you shouldn't be working on passion projects while your suppost to be working on a doll, they initially won, until a bunch of incriminating documents from the higher ups were leaked in court, displaying cut throat market strategies to kill Bratz. Bratz dolls are NOT better than barbie. At all.    Many people seem to think theyâ€™re allowed to express the opinion that Bratz dolls are better than Barbie dolls. This is simply false in every way. Some like to make the argument that Bratz dolls are more fashionable and have better bodies than barbie. Bratz dolls outfits are just all over the place. Detachable feet? You HAVE to remove their feet entirely just to change their shoes? Thatâ€™s terribly bad design. Barbie is allowed to go barefoot whenever she pleases, making her much more realistic. Barbies outfits are clean, and appealing to the eyes.    I believe that this opinion of Bratz dolls superiority over Barbie stems from peopleâ€™s need to feel different, and unique. Its no lie that Barbie is much more successful than Bratz dolls, and for good reason too. Thinking that Bratz dolls are better is barbaric and uncivilized. I havenâ€™t even gotten through half of the reasons why Barbie is better.   Another example for why Barbie reigns superior over Bratz is her contribution to society as a positive role-model for children, especially young girls. Barbie has had over 200 careers, making her an inspiration to girls as a whole. Even if Bratz dolls were more fashionable and physically appealing than Barbie, they would still not have left such a mark on society as Barbie has. That is because Bratz dolls value only money, while Barbie values change, progress, and representation. Barbie slander is not morally right, and frankly, its egregious.    A Bratz doll is but a shell of a little girl; though Barbie is an all-powerful being in the vessel of a woman.

Short story about why dolls are important: My dad literally brought me a Bratz doll and I didn't even watch a lot of Bratz episodes but he did it because he said she had brown hair like me and now I understand that he was trying for me to have representation. Since I have brown hair and tan skin, it was difficult to find a barbie with brown hair of course, so my mum had to buy me a Rachel (but I think she is asian?). The thing is that both my parents tried to show me some representation through the dolls and the closest they get was the Bratz doll, and it was important for me honestly, I never use my blonde barbie again. Okok time to explain the glasses they use to see pixies. Normal pixies can obviously be seen, like the evil pixies that attack that ball. 9:33 actualyl no, if you have long enough hair to wrap it around an anchor point, all the weight will be taken by the anchor point and not your scalp. I know this because I used to have long hair and when people tried to pull my hair in fights all I had to do was wrap the hair closer to my hear around my own arm and they couldn't cause me pain. It's all about where the pressure is being applied, hair is literally just a rope that happens to be attached to your head. A lot of rapunzel stories depict her wrapping the hair over a hook or around a bar in the window frame before casting it down.

It's not a bad thing, but a lot of dolls today comes in groups, so buying one doll from that line feels like a collectable fictional individual while Ken and others feel like an accessory unless you diverge them from Barbie. Like making Ken gay instead of Barbie's boyfriend. Otherwise you wouldn't really bother buying a doll from the line unless you like Barbie or it's the most convenient/cheap doll to get for a little kid.

Honestly, the Barbie movies growing up were definitely a source of comfort for me. Not to mention I felt like the dolls that I owned from those movies felt like friends to me! Bratz just...never appealed to me, the name alone just made them sound off-putting. I do understand why making dolls have weird body types and even sexual aspects is...fuckin' weird, to say the least. But even if the body images aren't great (it's getting better, though), the Barbie movies at least have way better messages, funny jokes, decent voice acting, and music that absolutely slaps. I think the Bratz dolls definitely win in terms of body diversity, but Barbies win in terms of appealing outfits and better films.

Actually! Mattel sued MGA (Bratz distributors) because the creator of Bratz, Carter Bryant, was working at Mattel when he came up the idea for the doll line and such that the creation of a separate brand infringed on their contract with him! They actually won the initial lawsuit and were awarded $100 million AND the copyright ownership to the Bratz line but the decision was reversed in 2010 by the Court of Appeals and ownership was given back to MGA! There was also a recall of all Bratz products for a time when Mattel had won the lawsuit! It was a really wild time lmao!

My little 6 year old brain took their band name literally, and got confused as to how they would be allowed to perform in concert as naked ladies! I'm just saying monster high dolls used to be super high quality. They had different faces and head shapes, they had wrist joints, elbow joints, knee joints, their arms could twist at the elbow and wrist, their arms didn't just move forward and backwards, you could move them and force them to T-pose. Their legs move in and out a bit, kinda. Their legs twist, their heads move up and down as well as side to side. They were super popular for doll customizing but you can't really buy them from stores anymore. You gotta buy them secondhand.

Wait did Barbie invent the "Rapunzel is a secret princess" twist that Disney used? bc that's not in the original fairytale - her parents are just normal people who stole from a witch's garden bc the wife had pregnancy cravings so the witch agreed to let the husband take it in exchange for the child. (And the plant he was stealing was rapunzel, hence the name.)  So looked on wikipedia to see if this comes from another variant and (1) doesn't seem to and (2) apparently in the original* (not original original, just the first grimm printing) grimm version she gets found out because she gets pregnant and they changed it to her accidentally asking Gothel why it's harder to pull her up than the prince to make it more kid-friendly....uh....

3:06 Naw, fam.  Barbie already had _plenty_ of Black, Hispanic, Asian, etc. versions _way_ before Bratz came out.  I know...because I _owned_ them.  Still had a few lying around until my kids finally broke the last one.  I was a little too old to be interested in dolls by the time Bratz came out, but I found the marketing off-putting, like they were promoting, well...being a _brat._  Barbies were the "You can be anything you want!" doll, but Bratz seemed more like the, "Spend all of Daddy's cash like there's no tomorrow and make duck-faces in all your selfies" doll.  Years later, when I had kids of my own and the girls wanted to watch Barbie movies/shows, I wasn't interested...until I overheard a few, and the writing is _hilarious._  The situations in the series are mostly absurd, and fittingly require absurd solutions, and I quite often catch myself snorting at a random overheard one-liner.  P.S. "People of color" is _so_ freaking cringe, it's just a re-wording of "colored people."  I'm *Black,* not "colored," and while I indeed appreciated _having_ different ethnicity dolls, I didn't _need_ one to feel "included," or whatever.  It wasn't "huge" b/c I am who I am regardless of whether or not a *doll* looks "like me."

I was never one for dolls as a kid. I was a big Power Rangers fan amd snuck out of my room to watch latenight movies, so I wanted to have cool fighting plotlines and huge dramatic plotlines. In hindsight my issue wasn't with the dolls themselves, it was that no other kids wanted to play the same game with them as me. So I'd settle playing house for a bit and then I'd get bored out of my damn mind and have my Barbie fall off the roof and be like "oh no... she died... later."  By myself, it was fun tho. I think it probably led to my bi/pan awakening, too, because I only had one Ken doll. So I would have the lady Barbies go to bed with each other, too. There would also be whole ass lifetime movies where one Barbie would catch Ken in bed with another Barbie and someone would get murdered and there'd be an investigation or the other Barbies just both dumped him, kicked him out of the house, and got married to each other. Also, lots of spy shit. Like, dolls don't have to be just one thing. They're just a jumping off point. You don't even need dolls. When, I was in the car, I'd do that thing where I'd make my hands walk on two fingers and have martial arts battles lol

BUT, and itâ€™s a BIG but, Bratz provided a monumental level of inclusivity and diversity to where ANY child with ANY hair, skin, or eye color combination could walk into a store and find a cute ass doll that looked exactly like them. While the Bratz may have not had many â€œcareersâ€ in their time they did travel the world in their little girl squad. Ok hereâ€™s my hot take: barbie had better movies but bratz had better dolls. Like with Barbie movies the magic world is generally pretty well designed and cohesive (when thereâ€™s a magic world in bratz itâ€™s pretty wack, for example the gnome thing and boring magic character designs like come on little girls donâ€™t want gnomes they want fucked up villain animal sidekicks and dragons), the animation holds up better than bratz (though that isnâ€™t saying much lol), the clothes translate better from doll to movie (a lot of bratz movies just use basic outfits for most scenes instead of actual unique doll outfits to save on animation costs, and when they do implement the actual doll designs they all look samey in basic outfit shape and color scheme [take the pixies here for example, the basic structure of the outfits is mesh long sleeve-T-shirt-tutu-jeans, just with different placements of the same colors] and it all just makes it difficult to tell each character apart, whereas when barbie has other characters with her same face the outfits always look distinct even if theyâ€™re just gowns, the shapes and colors are different enough to be recognizable but still look good together. Though the bad 3d animation might contribute to the bratz looking bad, because in the one 2D movie they all look great so idk lol). And the Bratz dolls are better because of diversity (barbie princess dolls only came in two options, white or black, no in between), outfit variation (I know I dunked on them in the animation, but in doll form they look amazing, and the outfits are always more than just one gown so you can mix and match different clothing items), makeup (many distinct eyeshadow looks and some have really glittery lips which is fun, this does just come down to personal preference but to me as a kid I always thought it made each one look more interesting even among different iterations of the same character, whereas if you took all the barbie princess dolls and removed their clothes+accessories, their makeup would all be very similar), the proportions/art style is unique, I guess this one comes down to personal preference as well because nothing wrong with a basic semi-realistic thing barbie has going on. Ok damn I just wrote a whole essay. I liked the Bratz dolls better as a kid, because Barbie dolls were usually more expensive and had less accessories. HOWEVER Barbie will still always be superior in regards to the movies. The Bratz movies never kept my ADHD ridden child brain entertained, but on the other hand, there wasn't a single Barbie movie that I didn't absolutely adore. I watched those movies on repeat, especially Princess and The Pauper. I still love Barbie movies, even as a 19 year old, because they're just so nostalgic. The newer ones have been pretty bad lately, but the old ones are absolutely stunning, and still hold up today. I also like Barbie's personality/persona more than the Bratz girl's; the Bratz had sassy and relatable type personas, while Barbie had more of a graceful role model persona. Okay but hear me out, the extra greeting is not actually an extra greeting. The first greeting is greeting those who are new to the channel and the "extra greeting" is a greeting for those who aren't new and are subscribed members of KurtisTown. With that in mind, it would mean that both greetings are for two different groups of people and would not be an 'extra' greeting for the subscribed member

It is actually perfectly plausible that climbing up Rapunzelâ€™s hair wouldnâ€™t hurt her. This is because of the way she wrapped her hair around the post. This releases the tension from her scalp and it acts like a rope. Itâ€™s like a pulley system, and it provides some slack that allows her to support that weight without scalping herself. The problem here is the actual weight of her hair. Perhaps she gets used to the weight by building up that muscle, but pulling so much weight constantly is effectively tearing her scalp apart.
